Applying for a Master's Degree in Singapore (NUS/NTU) | Generated by AI

Home 2025.10

1. Research Programs and Universities

  • Identify Programs: Determine the specific master’s program you are interested in. Singapore universities like NUS and NTU offer a wide range of programs in various disciplines.
  • University Reputation: Consider the university’s ranking, faculty, research opportunities, and industry collaborations.

2. Eligibility Criteria

  • Academic Qualifications: Typically, a bachelor’s degree in a relevant field is required. Some programs may require specific undergraduate courses or a minimum GPA.
  • English Proficiency: Proof of English language proficiency through tests like TOEFL, IELTS, or PTE is often required.
  • Entrance Exams: Some programs may require GMAT or GRE scores, especially for business and engineering programs.

3. Application Timeline

  • Application Deadlines: Deadlines vary by program and intake. The main intake is usually in August, but there may be other intakes in January or May. Check the specific program’s deadline on the university website.
  • Early Application: It is advisable to apply 7-12 months before the intended start date, as the application process can be competitive and time-consuming.

4. Application Process

  • Online Application: Most universities use an online application portal. Create an account and fill out the application form carefully.
  • Supporting Documents: Prepare and upload the required documents, which may include:
    • Academic transcripts
    • English language test scores
    • GMAT/GRE scores (if applicable)
    • Resume/CV
    • Statement of purpose
    • Letters of recommendation
    • Passport copy and other identification documents

5. Application Fees

  • Payment: Pay the non-refundable application fee, which varies by university. For example, NUS charges SGD 100 for graduate applications.
  • Payment Methods: Payment can usually be made online via credit card or other accepted methods.

6. Visa and Immigration

  • Student Pass: International students need a Student Pass to study in Singapore. The application for this pass is usually submitted through the university after acceptance.
  • Visa Requirements: Check the specific visa requirements for Chinese citizens and prepare the necessary documents, such as financial statements and health insurance.

7. Scholarships and Funding

  • Scholarship Opportunities: Research scholarship opportunities offered by the university, Singapore government, or external organizations.
  • Funding: Consider other funding options, such as loans or personal savings, to cover tuition and living expenses.

8. Post-Application

  • Interview: Some programs may require an interview as part of the application process. Prepare for potential interviews by researching common questions and practicing your responses.
  • Acceptance: If accepted, you will receive an offer letter. Follow the instructions provided to secure your place in the program, which may include paying a deposit or confirming your acceptance.

9. Pre-Departure

  • Accommodation: Arrange for accommodation, either on-campus or off-campus. On-campus housing is limited, so apply early if interested.
  • Health Insurance: Ensure you have adequate health insurance coverage for the duration of your studies.
  • Travel Arrangements: Book your travel to Singapore and familiarize yourself with the local customs and regulations.

10. Arrival and Orientation

  • Orientation: Attend orientation programs offered by the university to help you settle in and meet other students.
  • Support Services: Utilize university support services, such as academic advising, career services, and counseling, to enhance your academic and personal experience.

By following this comprehensive guide, you can navigate the application process for a master’s degree in Singapore with confidence. Good luck with your application!

It appears you might be asking about the fees for a Master’s degree in Computer Science at NUS and NTU. Here’s a breakdown of the estimated costs for international students based on the information found:

National University of Singapore (NUS):

  • Application Fee: SGD 100 (approximately)
  • Tuition Fees (per year):
    • Master of Computing (Computer Science Specialisation): Around SGD 40,693 - SGD 57,280 (These figures can vary slightly depending on the specific specialisation and intake year). Some sources quote around SGD 41,563 per year for general Computing graduate programs.
    • Keep in mind that programs can be 1 to 2 years in duration.
  • Acceptance Fee: SGD 5,450 (non-refundable, credited towards tuition fees for some programs like MComp).
  • Miscellaneous Student Fees: Approximately SGD 105 - SGD 109 per year.
  • Estimated Living Expenses: SGD 10,400 per year (including accommodation, food, personal expenses, transportation, and books). This is an estimate and can vary based on your lifestyle.

Nanyang Technological University (NTU):

  • Application Fee: Varies by program, check the specific program.
  • Tuition Fees (per year):
    • Master of Science in Computer Science: Around SGD 40,000 (This is an estimate based on general postgraduate fees and might vary for the specific Computer Science program).
    • M.A. Computing: Around SGD 22,300 for the 2024 intake (1-year program). Note that this might be a different program than the M.Sc. in Computer Science.
  • Registration Fee: SGD 500 for international students (non-refundable).
  • Estimated Living Expenses: Similar to NUS, factor in around SGD 1,500 - SGD 3,000 per month for living expenses depending on your lifestyle.

Important Considerations:

  • GST (Goods and Services Tax): Singapore’s GST is currently 9% (as of January 1, 2024) and is usually included in the quoted tuition fees.
  • Scholarships: Both NUS and NTU offer various scholarships for international students, which can significantly reduce the financial burden. Make sure to research and apply for relevant scholarships.
  • Fee Variations: Tuition fees can change annually and may vary between different specializations within the Computer Science department. Always check the official program websites for the most accurate and up-to-date fee information.
  • Other Costs: Remember to budget for your student pass application fee, health insurance, and pre-departure expenses.

Therefore, for a Master’s degree in Computer Science at either NUS or NTU, you should expect to pay:

  • Application Fee: Around SGD 100 (NUS) or variable (NTU).
  • First Year Tuition Fee: In the range of SGD 40,000 to SGD 58,000 approximately, depending on the university and the specific program.
  • Other Fees: Factor in acceptance fees (if applicable), registration fees (NTU), and miscellaneous fees.
  • Living Expenses: Budget at least SGD 12,000 to SGD 36,000 per year for your living costs.

It is crucial to visit the official websites of the specific Computer Science Master’s programs at NUS and NTU you are interested in to find the precise and current fee structures.

Yes, it is generally possible for international students who have obtained a Master’s degree from NUS or NTU in Singapore to stay and work in the country after graduation. Here’s a breakdown of the process and important considerations:

1. Work Visa Options:

After graduation, your student pass will expire. To work legally in Singapore, you will need to apply for a relevant work visa. The primary options for Master’s degree graduates typically fall under the following categories:

  • Employment Pass (EP): This is for foreign professionals, managers, and executives. To be eligible, you generally need a job offer in a managerial, executive, or specialized role and must meet the minimum salary requirements, which are currently SGD 5,600 per month (as of January 1, 2025) and increase with age. For the financial services sector, the minimum is SGD 6,200 per month. Employers usually sponsor this pass. Having a degree from a reputable university like NUS or NTU can be advantageous for EP applications.
  • S Pass: This is for mid-level skilled workers. The minimum salary requirement is lower than the EP, currently at least SGD 3,150 per month (as of September 1, 2023), and it also considers factors like qualifications, skills, and work experience. There’s a quota for S Pass holders that companies can employ.
  • Personalised Employment Pass (PEP): This is for high-earning professionals and offers more flexibility than an EP. However, the eligibility criteria are stringent, requiring a fixed salary of at least SGD 270,000 per calendar year for overseas applicants. It’s usually for very experienced professionals.
  • Overseas Networks & Expertise (ONE) Pass: This pass is for top talent in various fields and does not require a prior job offer. Applicants need to demonstrate a high monthly salary (at least SGD 30,000) or outstanding achievements in their field.

2. The Application Process:

  • Job Offer: The crucial first step is to secure a job offer from a company in Singapore. Your university’s career services and various job portals can be helpful resources.
  • Employer Sponsorship: Usually, your prospective employer will need to apply for the work pass on your behalf through the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) online portal.
  • Required Documents: You will typically need to provide documents such as your passport, degree certificate, transcripts, employment contract, and other supporting documents as requested by MOM.
  • Processing Time: The processing time for work pass applications can vary.
  • In-Principle Approval (IPA): If your application is successful initially, your employer will receive an IPA letter from MOM. You will then need to enter Singapore (if you are overseas) or complete further formalities in Singapore to get the actual work pass issued.
  • Work Pass Card: Once the process is complete, you will receive a work pass card.

3. Important Considerations:

  • Job Market: While Singapore has a robust economy with opportunities in various sectors, the job market can be competitive. Computer Science graduates, in particular, often find good prospects in Singapore’s growing technology industry.
  • Eligibility Criteria: Ensure you meet the specific eligibility criteria for the work pass you are applying for. These criteria can change, so always refer to the latest information on the MOM website.
  • Complementarity Assessment Framework (COMPASS): For Employment Pass applications, MOM uses COMPASS, a points-based system that assesses applicants based on various individual and firm-related attributes to ensure they complement the local workforce.
  • Tuition Grant Scheme: If you received a Tuition Grant from the Singapore government for your Master’s degree, you might be obligated to work for a Singapore-registered company for a specific period (typically three years) after graduation.
  • Permanent Residency (PR): After working in Singapore for a certain period (usually a few years) on a work pass, you may be eligible to apply for Permanent Residency. Recent policy changes have also made it potentially easier for eligible international students to apply for PR after passing certain national exams or being enrolled in integrated programs.
  • Work Pass Exemption for Students: While holding a student pass, there are limited conditions under which you can work part-time during term or full-time during vacation. However, once you graduate, you will need a valid work pass to continue working.

In summary, obtaining a Master’s degree in Computer Science from NUS or NTU significantly enhances your prospects of finding employment in Singapore. By securing a job offer that meets the criteria for an Employment Pass or other relevant work passes, you can transition from being a student to a working professional in Singapore. It’s essential to start your job search early, understand the work visa application process, and ensure you meet all the necessary requirements.
